5. Archaeological Investigation 

Archaeological investigations of the site included excavations at the location of the former residence 
and associated yard area to determine whether archaeological deposits were preserved within the site. 
The excavations were designed to thoroughly investigate identified archaeological deposits and features 
and were completed in accordance with the excavation methods detailed in Section 5.3.' metadata={'source': '/home/unimelb.edu.au/hamzeie/Desktop/hv_hackathon/data/5174_Excavation Report 2 H7822-2386_Stationmaster residence.pdf'}

page_content='6.2 Trench B: Stationmasters Residence yard 
A 2x2 m excavation was located at the rear of the former yard of the residence. The location was selected 
based  on  historical  plans  indicating  a  former  outhouse  or  ancillary  structure  at  this  location.  Recorded 
contexts within Trench B are detailed in Table 4. The location of the excavation is shown in Figure 55 and 
excavation photos are shown in Figure 20 and Figure 21.' metadata={'source': '/home/unimelb.edu.au/hamzeie/Desktop/hv_hackathon/data/5174_Excavation Report 2 H7822-2386_Stationmaster residence.pdf'}

page_content='An archaeological excavation program was completed in March 2020. The purpose of the archaeological 
program was to expose and record archaeological deposits or features associated with the historic use 
of the site. The site was subsequently merged into H7833-2386. 

The site was excavated in accordance to measures detailed in Consent to Disturb C1482 (Appendix A). 
Excavation  methods  are  included  detailed  Section  5.3.  This  archaeological  excavation  report  fulfils 
Condition 20 of the Consent C1493 issued by the Executive Director, Heritage Victoria.

© ECO LOGICAL AUSTRALIA PTY LTD

page_content='The excavation locations are shown in Figure 3, and included a total area of 60 m2. A further 30 m x 9 m 
area at the location of the former rifle range was also investigated and recorded under the conditions 
of a Watching Brief (Section 5.4). 

5.1 Field program and personnel 
The  archaeological  excavation  of  H7822-2384  took  place  on  18-20th  March  and  7th  April  2020.  The 
mechanical excavator and operators were supplied by NWPA. The excavation team included: 

Table 2: Excavation team and roles 

Team member 

Position 

Zachary Jones 

Project Manager 

Cathy Tucker 

Trench Supervisor 

Caroline Hawker 

Field Archaeologist

Field Archaeologist 

Anthony Gowans 

Field Archaeologist 

Daniel Claggett 

Field Archaeologist' metadata={'source': '/home/unimelb.edu.au/hamzeie/Desktop/hv_hackathon/data/5174_Excavation Report 2 H7822-2386_Stationmaster residence.pdf'}

page_content='The  soil  profile  across  the  rifle  range  area  comprised  an  upper  deposit  of  topsoil  (D001),  consistent 
across the entire site. Cuts for modern utilities (VicTrack) were also noted (D005). The greater majority 
of exposed surface area was characterised by a mixed demolition deposit of silts and clays associated 
with the removal of the rifle range (D002). The deposit contained brick fragments and modern materials 
intermixed with artefacts associated with the use of the rifle range. This included structural elements, 
such as timber floor supports, and artefacts including bullet casings, directly associated to the rifle range. 
A  number  of  historic  materials  attributed  to  domestic  activity  were  also  identified  along  with  rail 
componentry, such as rail spikes. The trench was subdivided into 5m sections (N-S) to facilitate the more 
accurate recording of artefact densities across D002 Each 5m section was allocated a context number:' metadata={'source': '/home/unimelb.edu.au/hamzeie/Desktop/hv_hackathon/data/5174_Excavation Report 2 H7822-2386_Stationmaster residence.pdf'}

2.paragraph: Example: The former stationmaster's residence and rifle range in the suburbs of Melbourne, Victoria, Australia is located in a rural area.

page_content='The  site  of  the  former  station  master’s  residence  and  rifle  range  are  of  scientific  (archaeological) 
significance for its potential to provide evidence of residential and recreational/ sporting use associated 
with the railway line and railway corridor. There is potential the former foundations of the house, rifle 
range  and  associated  artefacts  to  be  preserved  within  the  site  extent  that  may  provide  significant 
information  regarding  the  former  activities  and  practises  of  individuals  occupying  or  using  these 
structures.   

The site addresses the following category in Victoria’s Framework of Historical Themes: 

Connecting Victorians by transport and communications. 

• 

 Linking Victorians by rail 

The  site’s  significance  may  also  be  considered  with  regard  to  the  following  criteria  detailed  in  the 
Guidelines for Conducting Historical Archaeological Surveys:' metadata={'source': '/home/unimelb.edu.au/hamzeie/Desktop/hv_hackathon/data/5174_Excavation Report 2 H7822-2386_Stationmaster residence.pdf'}

2.2 Description 
VHI 7822-2384 encompassed an area of Gandolfo Gardens approximately 50 m in length and 30 m in 
width, situated along the western side of the Upfield rail corridor opposite Moreland Station.  

The site is covered by the City of Moreland planning scheme heritage overlays HO115 (Moreland Station 
Precinct, Coburg) and HO180 (Upfield Railway Line Precinct).  

Surfaces within the site at the time of the investigation were primarily grassed, with evidence of recent 
superficial impacts from vehicle use and tree removal (Figure 1, Figure 2). 

© ECO LOGICAL AUSTRALIA PTY LTD
